title: My Hands Were a Disaster Until I Tried This Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm
body:
Okay so my hands. They were bad. Like, cracking and red and just angry at me all winter bad. I was using this lotion from the drugstore, the one in the blue bottle that’s always on sale for like $4.79, and it wasn’t doing anything. It just sat on top of my skin and felt sticky. I was scrolling on my phone one night, my heater making that clicking noise it does, and I saw someone talking about beef tallow skincare. For your face. I was like, beef fat? On your skin? That sounds… not great. But then I kept seeing it. And my hands were so bad I figured, whatever, can’t get worse. I found this little Etsy shop that makes a whipped tallow balm, and they had a Bourbon Vanilla scent. I like vanilla. It sounded less weird than the unscented one. So I ordered it.

It showed up on a Tuesday, I think. The jar was smaller than I pictured. But solid. Heavy glass. I unscrewed the lid right there in my kitchen, the overhead light was too bright as usual. And I smelled it.

It didn’t smell like beef. At all. That was my first worry. It smelled like… okay. It smelled like vanilla. But not like cake vanilla. Or candle vanilla. It was like if you walked into a warm kitchen where someone was baking something with real vanilla beans a few hours ago, and the smell just hung around, got cozy with the wood of the cabinets. It was a warm smell. A comforting smell. Not sweet in a gross way. Just… nice. Really nice. I poked it with my finger. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was solid but soft, like cold butter straight from the fridge, but when you press into it, it gives way and feels almost creamy. I scooped a little out.

### What Even Is a Tallow Balm?

So I had to look this up after I bought it, because I’m putting cow fat on my hands and I felt I should know. This bourbon vanilla tallow balm is basically whipped beef fat. Tallow. From grass-fed cows, made in France apparently. The idea, which sounded nuts to me at first, is that it’s really similar to the oils our own skin makes. So instead of just sitting on top like my cheap lotion, it sinks in. It mimics your skin’s sebum. My skin’s sebum was clearly on strike, so I needed a replacement.

I was skeptical. Of course I was. It sounds like something your great-grandmother might have used before there were drugstores. But then I thought, maybe that’s the point. Maybe they knew something. My $50 fancy face cream wasn’t fixing my knuckles, so.

### How This Vanilla Smell Makes Me Actually Use the Stuff

Here’s the thing about skincare. If I don’t like doing it, I won’t do it. I have a graveyard of half-used serums under my sink to prove it. But this bourbon vanilla tallow balm? I look forward to it. It’s become this little thing.

I keep the jar on my nightstand. My routine is basically non-existent, but now, before I turn the light off, I grab it. The ritual is simple. Unscrew the lid. That first smell hits me. It’s not a perfume smell, it’s a *comfort* smell. It smells like a blanket feels. I scoop out a tiny bit—a little goes a seriously long way—and rub it between my palms. It melts instantly from the heat of your hands. It goes from that firm balm to this rich, almost oily-but-not-greasy oil. Then I just massage it into my hands. My cuticles. My wrists. The weird dry patch on my thumb I get every winter.

I just sit there for a minute in the dark, rubbing my hands, smelling that warm vanilla. My brain finally shuts up. The day’s junk—the work emails, the weird noise my car started making, the fact I need to buy groceries—it all just fades for a second. It’s a sensory reset button. The scent is the whole reason I’m consistent with it. If it was unscented or had some weird herbal smell, I’d forget. But this natural bourbon vanilla skincare moment? It’s my two-minute vacation. I’m not even kidding.

### So Did This Scented Tallow Balm Actually Do Anything?

Yeah. It did.

The first week, I noticed my hands just felt… quieter. The tight, itchy feeling was gone. They felt softer. Not slippery soft, but like my own skin again. After maybe two weeks, the cracks on my knuckles started to actually heal. They weren’t these red, painful lines anymore. They were just… gone. My elbows, which are always rough, felt smooth for the first time in maybe a decade. I don’t look at my elbows much, but I noticed in the shower.

The wildest part was how it absorbed. You’d think beef fat would be greasy. This isn’t. You rub it in and it’s like your skin drinks it. Within a minute or two, my hands aren’t slick. I can pick up my phone. Turn the page of a book. It’s just gone, but my skin feels cushioned. Protected. I started using a tiny, tiny bit on my cheeks at night when the wind had chapped them. Same thing. No breakouts. Just relief.

I got brave and used it on a patch of eczema on my ankle. I’ve had that thing for years. It’s not magic, it didn’t vanish overnight, but the itching calmed down so much. The skin looked less angry. Less like it wanted to start a fight.

### Would I Buy This Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm Again?

I’m on my second jar. I ordered one for my mom for Christmas because her hands get bad in the winter too. She called me confused at first (“You bought me what?”) and then she called me two weeks later to tell me she needed the link to the shop.

That’s the real review, I guess. When you buy it for someone else.

It’s not a miracle in a jar. It’s not going to make you look 20 again. But if your skin is dry, or cracked, or just pissed off at the cold weather, this stuff works. It genuinely, actually works. And the scent makes using it a treat, not a chore. I don’t know how else to say it. My hands aren’t a disaster anymore. They’re just… my hands. And they smell nice.

### Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yeah. Because it’s so similar to the oils our skin already makes, it absorbs really well and doesn’t just clog stuff up. My face likes it more than a lot of the fancy stuff I’ve tried. Just use a tiny amount.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was worried about this too. But no, not for me. It’s non-comedogenic, which means it’s not supposed to. It sinks in instead of sitting on top. If you’re super oily, maybe just use it on dry spots.

**What does the Bourbon Vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
It’s hard to describe scents. It’s not food vanilla. It’s warm and cozy and a little deep, like vanilla mixed with something that just makes it feel comforting. Not sugary. Just… nice. Really pleasant.

Anyway. If your skin’s being difficult this winter, this might be worth a shot. I got mine from that Etsy shop, Malti. My hands are happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.
